content:
@Damiano Testa You've pushed this file to a branch, and then also made it a pull request. I think a lot of it looks great, but there are also some sorrys left. Would you be interested in polishing this to get it into mathlib? I'm sure there are several people here who could help with that.

Usually (and especially for first PRs) we encourage people to PR < 300 lines of code. So what you could do, is split this file into pieces, and PR it in smaller bits. (You can leave this one open, so that people can see where you are heading.)

I can try to fill in the sorrys, but the ones that are left are the ones that I have not been able to "convert". The commented proofs are the proofs of the corresponding statements in the original leading_coeff format that I have not been able to convert.

I will split the file, though, since I think that I was able to convert most of the initial proofs and only started having problems somewhere into the file

Johan Commelin said:

Usually (and especially for first PRs) we encourage people to PR < 300 lines of code. So what you could do, is split this file into pieces, and PR it in smaller bits. (You can leave this one open, so that people can see where you are heading.)

Magically, the proofs are complete until line 295!
so, breaking off one file is easy: I simply cut out the tail
The new file, though will rely on (some of) the results of the former, though. Should I import the former in the latter?
(Follow-up PRs don't have to start new files. They can simply append. But files with >1000 lines tend to get split.)
What is the "former file"?
Ah, ok! The trailing part could be appended to leading, but I think that it is best to separate them, then, in view of the length comment

I will shorten the current trailing file, with the complete proofs and upload it. after that, I will merge the rest of the file, but wait to do a PR until after the first half has been reviewed. sounds reasonable?

What you can do is on the branch trailing_degree you run git checkout -b trailing_degree1. Then you have a new branch (and it is immediately checked out). On that new branch, you delete the last 2/3rds of the file. And then push, and open a new PR.

So

git checkout trailing_degree   # Make sure you depart from the current PR (and not some other branch)
git checkout -b trailing_degree_1   # Start a new branch
# edit the file
git commit -am "feat(trailing_degree): definitions and basic properties"
git push
Once that new PR is merged, you can then repeat this process to create a 2nd PR. that contains the middle bit.

I get this error

git checkout -c trailing_degree_1
error: unknown switch `c'
Ooh, maybe it's -b? [Note: updated the instructions above.]

yes!

Switched to a new branch 'trailing_degree_1'

Sorry, I chopped off part of the file, saved and exited VSC and then I get this error

git commit -am "feat(trailing_degree): definitions and basic properties"
On branch trailing_degree_1
nothing to commit, working tree clean
Weird...
What happens if you open the file in VScode again?
it opens the chopped off file

I also have a red squiggly line on the last end, error

invalid end of module, expecting 'end'
Right, you need to close some namespace or section
The chopping off should be done in an elegant and civilized manner :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes: :stuck_out_tongue_wink:

just to make sure, my computer thinks that this file was edited now:

 ls -ao src/data/polynomial/degree
total 260
drwxrwxr-x 2 damiano   4096 Sep 11 12:51 .
drwxrwxr-x 3 damiano   4096 Sep 11 12:51 ..
-rw-rw-r-- 1 damiano  31479 Sep  8 11:25 basic.lean
-rw-r--r-- 1 damiano 187512 Sep  8 11:26 basic.olean
-rw-rw-r-- 1 damiano  11895 Sep 11 12:51 trailing_degreeBasic.lean
-rw-rw-r-- 1 damiano  24530 Sep 11 12:45 trailing_tail.lean
In the bottom left corner, VScode shows you which branch it is working on. What does it say?
(trailing_tail is the severed body)

image.png
trailing_degree_1
Hmm, so if you save this, then in the terminal, I would expect git status to tell you that some files have changed.
You created trailing_degreeBasic.lean after you ran git checkout -b, right?
You'll need to git add trailing_degreeBasic.lean in that case.
I think Johan was assuming you would just edit the original file.

Lean/mathlib_trailing_degree$ git status
On branch trailing_degree_1
nothing to commit, working tree clean
Lean/mathlib_trailing_degree$ ls -ao src/data/polynomial/degree
total 260
drwxrwxr-x 2 damiano   4096 Sep 11 12:52 .
drwxrwxr-x 3 damiano   4096 Sep 11 12:52 ..
-rw-rw-r-- 1 damiano  31479 Sep  8 11:25 basic.lean
-rw-r--r-- 1 damiano 187512 Sep  8 11:26 basic.olean
-rw-rw-r-- 1 damiano  11895 Sep 11 12:54 trailing_degreeBasic.lean
-rw-rw-r-- 1 damiano  24530 Sep 11 12:45 trailing_tail.lean

Rob Lewis said:

You'll need to git add trailing_degreeBasic.lean in that case.

I do not remember, but I certainly have created the trailing_tail file after the -b
No, that file already existed https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/4069/files
I will try with git add
But we don't want that trailing_tail.lean in the new PR, right?
no, for the moment, no
Also, it's weird that git status doesn't tell you about the new files

Lean/mathlib_trailing_degree/src/data/polynomial/degree$ git status
On branch trailing_degree_1
nothing to commit, working tree clean
Lean/mathlib_trailing_degree/src/data/polynomial/degree$ git add trailing_degreeBasic.lean
Lean/mathlib_trailing_degree/src/data/polynomial/degree$ git status
On branch trailing_degree_1
nothing to commit, working tree clean
Lean/mathlib_trailing_degree/src/data/polynomial/degree$ ls
basic.lean  basic.olean  trailing_degreeBasic.lean  trailing_tail.lean
Aaah, did you hit some git buttons in VScode?
I did...
What does git log say? (First 20 lines or so?)
was I not supposed to?
It's ok...
Just means that you don't need to do the commit in the terminal (-;
Just take a look at the git log.

Lean/mathlib_trailing_degree/src/data/polynomial/degree$ git log |head -20
commit 1562bcb93b3f5d8e796bf0da04d6ecf971000c79
Author: adomani <adomani@gmail.com>
Date:   Fri Sep 11 12:46:03 2020 +0200

    chopped off the part without proofs

commit 5dd9683c5cb68c42f11f28b2aa2ba21b0e4bbfe5
Author: adomani <adomani@gmail.com>
Date:   Tue Sep 8 11:34:17 2020 +0200

    added statements for trailing_degree, nat_trailing_degree, trailing_coeff,...  Many proofs are missing!

commit a16112d3eac76496b5783e0ea49246d8c0c07377
Author: Reid Barton <rwbarton@gmail.com>
Date:   Tue Sep 8 00:47:47 2020 +0000

    doc(algebra/group/to_additive): order of to_additive relative to other attributes (#4065)

commit c7d6a8e753bff02e8998b959f392a9da46c8f587
Author: Aaron Anderson <awainverse@gmail.com>
There you go (-;
so I am all set?
should I commit?
So you are ready to git push
ah, push! hahaha

Damiano Testa said:

should I commit?

No, it's done already

git push --set-upstream origin trailing_degree_1

then

Lean/mathlib_trailing_degree/src/data/polynomial/degree$ git push --set-upstream origin trailing_degree_1
Enumerating objects: 14, done.
Counting objects: 100% (14/14), done.
Delta compression using up to 6 threads
Compressing objects: 100% (8/8), done.
Writing objects: 100% (8/8), 6.17 KiB | 1.23 MiB/s, done.
Total 8 (delta 5), reused 0 (delta 0)

from this :up: bit
I think that I did it, like last time
are the errors normal? Lean on my computer compiled it without errors/sorry's
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/runs/1101406898
So the end didn't make it to github
Also, you should update your PR title to follow the guidelines: https://github.com/leanprover-community/lean/blob/master/doc/commit_convention.md

so, should I commit it again and write

feat(data.polynomial.degree): added trailing_degree, trailing_nat_degree, trailing_coeff and various lemmas
add functionality to work with trailing coefficients
But change the . to / (yes, inconsistency....)
Also, in that commit, I guess you are only add end ( right?)
The title of that commit will not change the title of the PR, so it doesn't matter what you do
To change the title of the PR, go to the github page, and click on the edit button next to the title
Whatever is in the title on the PR page (and in the first post, above the line with ---) will be turned into the commit message for the master branch when the PR gets merged.
So individual commits in a PR can have pretty ugly commit messages, that doesn't matter.
I changed the title, but it does not look right...

Johan Commelin said:

Also, in that commit, I guess you are only add end ( right?)

Should I add an extra end at the bottom of the .lean file?
(if I do, then this last end is the one with the red underlining)
Hmm, what does it say when you hover over the readlines?
I would expect that you need end polynomial at some point
Maybe there where multiple namespaces and sections open?
I guess you can type #where to find out

image.png 

invalid end of scope, begin/end mismatch, scope starts with 'semiring', and ends with '[anonymous]'Lean
invalid end of module, expecting 'end'Lean
Peek Problem (Alt+F8)
No quick fixes available
Aha, so end semiring

but typing end semiring gives 

invalid end of module, expecting 'end'Lean
Peek Problem (Alt+F8)
No quick fixes available
hmm, what does #where say?

#where
namespace polynomial

open finset finsupp function
variables {R : Type u} {S : Type v} {b a : R} {m n : ℕ} {q p : polynomial R} {ι : Type u_1} [semiring R]



end polynomial
i'll try end polynomial

trailing_degreeBasic.lean:297:0
invalid end of scope, begin/end mismatch, scope starts with 'semiring', and ends with 'polynomial'
trailing_degreeBasic.lean:297:14
invalid end of module, expecting 'end'

end semiring
end polynomial
this works!
so, I will upload git push it again to github, then?

I believe that I made progress, but there are still issues:

 leanpkg build
11s
##[error]Process completed with exit code 1.
Run leanpkg configure
configuring mathlib 0.1
/home/runner/work/mathlib/mathlib/src/data/polynomial/degree/trailing_tail.lean:2:0: warning: using 'exit' to interrupt Lean

Build succeeded, but the following files were noisy:
src/data/polynomial/degree/trailing_tail.lean
##[error]Process completed with exit code 1.
I created a noisy file
Hmm... don't know where that came from
@Damiano Testa Aha... you also added the trailing_tail file
And that starts with #exit
I just pushed to your branch
So you can now git pull (or leanproject up)
Ah, ok, so how do I remove the trailing_tail file?
I also renamed the Basic file
git rm filename
But I already did that for you
Ok, I git pulled
I also added a label on the PR page
this means that now I have the same version as is in the github page, as a PR, right?
so, just to understand the process, once/if this gets incorporated into mathlib, I will then add the second half to this same file and I will hope that someone else can fill in the sorry's?
Or by that time you have levelled-up and can do them yourself (-;
(anyway, I am off next week, so it will have to wait for a bit!)

@Damiano Testa https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/runs/1101545585
the linter is "unhappy" :grinning:

If I understand correctly Lean's complaint, it is saying that one of the lemmas in the new file (trailing_degree) can prove directly one of the lemmas in the old file (basic). I think that I would rather eliminate the lemma in the new file, than touch the old file, so I will try to eliminate and see if the proofs continue to work. If they do, then I will commit the change. Does this sound reasonable?

actually, the lemma in the new file is

@[simp]
lemma next_coeff_up_C_eq_zero (c : R) :
  next_coeff (C c) = 0 := by { rw next_coeff, simp }

and changing the proof to

@[simp]
lemma next_coeff_up_C_eq_zero (c : R) :
  next_coeff (C c) = 0 := by { simp }

works. Should I then simply do this change and re-commit?
the linter is saying you have too many simp lemmas
not that you should remove the lemma completely
you can keep it as long as you don't tag it with @[simp]
Ok, I will then remove the simp tag and also shorten the proof to simp!
use simp only
@Damiano Testa The linter can sometimes be confused about which of the lemmas should be changed.
(use squeeze_simp and then follow the suggestion)
actually, I think that I know what is going on: the linter found a place where I did not change the lemma correctly!
so, I changed the lemma to what it "should" be and I will try uploading it again!
You can also write #lint at the bottom of the file.
Then you can at least see the local opinion of the linter.

indeed!

/- Checking 49 declarations (plus 7 automatically generated ones) in the current file -/


/- All linting checks passed! -/
(But the linter is not a sheaf, so if it is everywhere locally happy, you don't know if it is globally happy.)
yes, I was going to say that it does not seem like lint took into account the older file...
anyway, I will try as is and see if lint is happy now
Lean is linting...
aspeta per 30 minuti
aspetta per 30 minuti
If I understand correctly, the PR has been reviewed, right? I think that it is now #4113. Am I supposed to do something, or, in time, it will be merged?
Reviewers have brought up explicit points which they want you to deal with.
The PR is tagged "awaiting author" which means it's awaiting your response to some questions.
Ah, I see! I will look more for these questions!
You can just click on #4113 and you'll be taken to a github page where you can see the questions which have been raised.
@Damiano Testa And FYI, you can just edit the code on your branch, save, commit, push, and github will update the PR page automatically after that.
@Damiano Testa I've kicked your first PR onto the merge queue :octopus: :tada: :clink:
My first octopus! Ahaha Thank you!
